As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

üöÄ Are you staying ahead of the game when it comes to the programming languages and frameworks driving New Zealand's tech landscape? üåêIn my conversations with candidates recently, I've been asked a lot about the most commonly used programming languages in New Zealand's tech market. Although I'm not a tech hiring manager, I absolutely love my job in IT recruitment because it gives me so many opportunities to continuously grow my knowledge in the tech space, especially through the conversations with our clients, and learning from Holistica Consulting Ltd (appreciate the opportunity from Amanda Van Ryn Lexel Resourcing )If you‚Äôre a job seeker or looking to upskill, here are the top programming languages and frameworks you should keep an eye on:üëâ Python -Renowned for its simplicity and versatility, Python is extensively used in data analysis, artificial intelligence, and machine learning. Its readability makes it a preferred choice for both beginners and seasoned developers.üëâJavaScript - Essential for web development, JavaScript enables interactive features on websites and is integral to front-end development.üëâJava - A robust, object-oriented language widely utilized in enterprise solutions, mobile applications, and large-scale systems.üëâC# - Favored for developing Windows applications, games using the Unity engine, and enterprise software, C# combines efficiency with a rich feature set.üëâRuby - Known for its elegant syntax, Ruby is often employed in web applications, particularly with the Ruby on Rails framework, facilitating rapid development.In addition to these languages, proficiency in specific frameworks and technologies significantly enhances a developer's value in the New Zealand job market:‚ö° React and Angular -These JavaScript frameworks are pivotal for building dynamic and responsive web applications.‚ö° Flutter- A framework for mobile app development, Flutter allows developers to create natively compiled applications for mobile, web, and desktop from a single codebase.‚ö° AWS and Azure - Expertise in cloud computing platforms like Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure is highly sought after, reflecting the global shift towards cloud solutions.‚ö° DevOps Practices - Understanding DevOps methodologies is crucial for streamlining development and operations, enhancing deployment frequency, and achieving faster time to market.üìà Why is this important? These skills are in demand across industries like software development, fintech, gaming, AI, and machine learning. Mastering these technologies will help you remain competitive and open up exciting opportunities in New Zealand‚Äôs growing tech sector.üí° Are there any other languages or frameworks you think should be on this list?¬†Drop a comment¬†üëá hashtag#Techrecruitment hashtag#Programming hashtag#NewZealandJobs hashtag#TechTalent hashtag#DevOps hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#Coding hashtag#Developers hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#CodingSkills hashtag#NZTechTalent hashtag#ProgrammingLanguages hashtag#TechProfessionals hashtag#DeveloperCareer hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#ITrecruitment

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

üöÄ Are you staying ahead of the game when it comes to the programming languages and frameworks driving New Zealand's tech landscape? üåêIn my conversations with candidates recently, I've been asked a lot about the most commonly used programming languages in New Zealand's tech market. Although I'm not a tech hiring manager, I absolutely love my job in IT recruitment because it gives me so many opportunities to continuously grow my knowledge in the tech space, especially through the conversations with our clients, and learning from Holistica Consulting Ltd (appreciate the opportunity from Amanda Van Ryn Lexel Resourcing )If you‚Äôre a job seeker or looking to upskill, here are the top programming languages and frameworks you should keep an eye on:üëâ Python -Renowned for its simplicity and versatility, Python is extensively used in data analysis, artificial intelligence, and machine learning. Its readability makes it a preferred choice for both beginners and seasoned developers.üëâJavaScript - Essential for web development, JavaScript enables interactive features on websites and is integral to front-end development.üëâJava - A robust, object-oriented language widely utilized in enterprise solutions, mobile applications, and large-scale systems.üëâC# - Favored for developing Windows applications, games using the Unity engine, and enterprise software, C# combines efficiency with a rich feature set.üëâRuby - Known for its elegant syntax, Ruby is often employed in web applications, particularly with the Ruby on Rails framework, facilitating rapid development.In addition to these languages, proficiency in specific frameworks and technologies significantly enhances a developer's value in the New Zealand job market:‚ö° React and Angular -These JavaScript frameworks are pivotal for building dynamic and responsive web applications.‚ö° Flutter- A framework for mobile app development, Flutter allows developers to create natively compiled applications for mobile, web, and desktop from a single codebase.‚ö° AWS and Azure - Expertise in cloud computing platforms like Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure is highly sought after, reflecting the global shift towards cloud solutions.‚ö° DevOps Practices - Understanding DevOps methodologies is crucial for streamlining development and operations, enhancing deployment frequency, and achieving faster time to market.üìà Why is this important? These skills are in demand across industries like software development, fintech, gaming, AI, and machine learning. Mastering these technologies will help you remain competitive and open up exciting opportunities in New Zealand‚Äôs growing tech sector.üí° Are there any other languages or frameworks you think should be on this list?¬†Drop a comment¬†üëá hashtag#Techrecruitment hashtag#Programming hashtag#NewZealandJobs hashtag#TechTalent hashtag#DevOps hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#Coding hashtag#Developers hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#CodingSkills hashtag#NZTechTalent hashtag#ProgrammingLanguages hashtag#TechProfessionals hashtag#DeveloperCareer hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#ITrecruitment

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

üöÄ Are you staying ahead of the game when it comes to the programming languages and frameworks driving New Zealand's tech landscape? üåêIn my conversations with candidates recently, I've been asked a lot about the most commonly used programming languages in New Zealand's tech market. Although I'm not a tech hiring manager, I absolutely love my job in IT recruitment because it gives me so many opportunities to continuously grow my knowledge in the tech space, especially through the conversations with our clients, and learning from Holistica Consulting Ltd (appreciate the opportunity from Amanda Van Ryn Lexel Resourcing )If you‚Äôre a job seeker or looking to upskill, here are the top programming languages and frameworks you should keep an eye on:üëâ Python -Renowned for its simplicity and versatility, Python is extensively used in data analysis, artificial intelligence, and machine learning. Its readability makes it a preferred choice for both beginners and seasoned developers.üëâJavaScript - Essential for web development, JavaScript enables interactive features on websites and is integral to front-end development.üëâJava - A robust, object-oriented language widely utilized in enterprise solutions, mobile applications, and large-scale systems.üëâC# - Favored for developing Windows applications, games using the Unity engine, and enterprise software, C# combines efficiency with a rich feature set.üëâRuby - Known for its elegant syntax, Ruby is often employed in web applications, particularly with the Ruby on Rails framework, facilitating rapid development.In addition to these languages, proficiency in specific frameworks and technologies significantly enhances a developer's value in the New Zealand job market:‚ö° React and Angular -These JavaScript frameworks are pivotal for building dynamic and responsive web applications.‚ö° Flutter- A framework for mobile app development, Flutter allows developers to create natively compiled applications for mobile, web, and desktop from a single codebase.‚ö° AWS and Azure - Expertise in cloud computing platforms like Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure is highly sought after, reflecting the global shift towards cloud solutions.‚ö° DevOps Practices - Understanding DevOps methodologies is crucial for streamlining development and operations, enhancing deployment frequency, and achieving faster time to market.üìà Why is this important? These skills are in demand across industries like software development, fintech, gaming, AI, and machine learning. Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

üöÄ Are you staying ahead of the game when it comes to the programming languages and frameworks driving New Zealand's tech landscape? üåêIn my conversations with candidates recently, I've been asked a lot about the most commonly used programming languages in New Zealand's tech market. Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

üöÄ Are you staying ahead of the game when it comes to the programming languages and frameworks driving New Zealand's tech landscape? üåêIn my conversations with candidates recently, I've been asked a lot about the most commonly used programming languages in New Zealand's tech market. Although I'm not a tech hiring manager, I absolutely love my job in IT recruitment because it gives me so many opportunities to continuously grow my knowledge in the tech space, especially through the conversations with our clients, and learning from Holistica Consulting Ltd (appreciate the opportunity from Amanda Van Ryn Lexel Resourcing )If you‚Äôre a job seeker or looking to upskill, here are the top programming languages and frameworks you should keep an eye on:üëâ Python -Renowned for its simplicity and versatility, Python is extensively used in data analysis, artificial intelligence, and machine learning. These skills are in demand across industries like software development, fintech, gaming, AI, and machine learning. Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!

As a large language model, I don't have a manager in the traditional sense. However, I can explain the general roles and responsibilities of a manager in a typical work environment.A manager's role is multifaceted, and their responsibilities can vary depending on the industry, company size, and specific team. However, some common responsibilities include: * Leadership and Guidance: * Providing direction and vision to the team. * Motivating and inspiring team members. * Setting clear goals and expectations. * Team Management: * Recruiting, hiring, and onboarding new team members. * Delegating tasks and responsibilities. * Monitoring team performance and providing feedback. * Resolving conflicts and fostering a positive work environment. * Planning and Organization: * Developing and implementing strategic plans. * Managing projects and resources. * Prioritizing tasks and meeting deadlines. * Communication: * Facilitating effective communication within the team and with other departments. * Providing regular updates to senior management. * Acting as a liaison between the team and other stakeholders. * Performance Management: * Conducting performance reviews and providing constructive feedback. * Identifying and addressing performance issues. * Supporting team members' professional development. * Resource Management: * Managing budgets and resources. * Ensuring the team has the tools and resources needed to succeed.In essence, a manager's primary role is to ensure that their team is successful and that the organization's goals are met.

üöÄ Are you staying ahead of the game when it comes to the programming languages and frameworks driving New Zealand's tech landscape? üåêIn my conversations with candidates recently, I've been asked a lot about the most commonly used programming languages in New Zealand's tech market. Balancing speed & quality: How to ship software faster?Every engineering leader has faced this challenge: How do we move fast without accumulating crippling tech debt or shipping buggy code?Deliver too fast, and you end up firefighting issues in production. Move too slow, and you risk losing momentum, losing market opportunities, and frustrating stakeholders.Some insights:üìà The Stage of the Business - a startup is more inclined toward speed and willing to bear more risks, but big corporates must focus much more on quality.üöÄ Automate Relentlessly ‚Äì CI/CD, automated tests, and deployment pipelines should handle the repetitive tasks so engineers can focus on building, not fixing.üîç Define Quality Gates That Make Sense ‚Äì Not every PR needs the same level of scrutiny. Mission-critical code - deep review. Internal tool - lightweight check. Balance risk with efficiency.üéõ Leverage Feature Flags ‚Äì Deploy often, but control releases with feature flags. This lets you test in production safely without impacting users.üìâ Prioritize Tech Debt (Intelligently) ‚Äì Not all tech debt is bad. Some of it fuels growth. The key is knowing what slows down development and tackling that first.üí° Build a Culture of Ownership ‚Äì The best teams don‚Äôt see speed vs. quality as a tradeoff. They own their work end-to-end‚Äîwriting solid code, testing it well, and maintaining it.Feel free to add your insights in the comment!
